title: Why is modern periodic table sometimes called Bohr's periodic table? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because people are mistaken. The periodic table was Medeleev’s genius (first published in 1860) and came up with the arrangement we have even though, at the time it was ‘invented’ many of the elements were unknown. From the periodic table many trends were observed - melting points, boiling points (of both the elements and compounds containing them), reactivity, likely empirical formulas. It even aided in the discovery of unknown elements. In the early 1900’s, Bohr came along and developed the theory of atomic structure with electrons located in ‘shells’ (e.g., 1s, 2s, 2p, etc) and this theory was extremely helpful for understanding many things (another story). Not too surprisingly, how these shells are organized is aligned with the arrangement of the atoms in the periodic table - which further points out just how powerful the periodic table is; many discoveries that came after the periodic table ‘fit’ in with the predictions of the table. I do not mean to diminish, in any way, the contributions that Bohr made, but only want to give credit where it is due, and for the periodic table it is Medeleev.

I would not say that the modern version of the periodic table is “Bohr’s periodic table”. The modern version of the periodic table is the result of the work by Glenn Seaborg. Instead, Bohr came up with several versions which were based on Mendeleev’s table.
